questions.explanation: To create a function, you must use the 'function' keyword, followed by the name of the function and parentheses. For example: 'function myFunction() { ... }'. 'def' is used in Python and 'sub' is used in languages like Perl or Basic.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of 'Arguments' (or Parameters) in a function?
options: To stop the function from executing if an error occurs.
To allow the function to receive and use data from the calling statement.
To provide a permanent storage location for the function's code.
To translate the function into machine language.
questions.explanation: Arguments are pieces of information you pass into a function. They allow the same function to perform work on different data. For example, a function that calculates a square needs the number to be squared as an argument.

questions.question: Where is the best place to define functions within an HTML document according to VU handouts?
options: Inside the <BODY> tag near the bottom.
Inside the <HEAD> section of the document.
Within a <DT> tag in a definition list.
questions.explanation: While JavaScript can be placed in the body, it is standard practice to define functions in the <HEAD> section. This ensures that the functions are loaded and ready to be used before any user interaction (like a button click in the body) tries to call them.

questions.question: When a function is called, what happens to the execution flow of the main script?
options: It continues running simultaneously with the function.
It stops and waits for the function to finish before continuing.
It restarts from the beginning of the HTML document.
It deletes all previous calculations to save memory.
questions.explanation: Function execution is synchronous. When the script 'calls' a function, the flow jumps to that function, executes its statements, and then returns to the exact point in the main script where the call was made to continue.

questions.question: In JavaScript, the values passed into a function are called 'Arguments'. What are these values called in the function definition?
questions.explanation: While often used interchangeably, 'parameters' are the aliases listed in the function definition (e.g., function add(a, b)), while 'arguments' are the actual values passed during the call (e.g., add(5, 10)).

questions.question: A variable that is declared *inside* a function and can only be used within that specific function is called a:
questions.explanation: Local variables have 'local scope.' They are created when the function starts and destroyed when it ends. They are not accessible by any other part of the script outside that specific function.

questions.question: What is a 'Global Variable'?
options: A variable that can be accessed from any function within the script.
A variable that works only if the computer is connected to the internet.
A variable that can only store numbers but not text.
A variable that is automatically deleted every 60 seconds.
questions.explanation: Global variables are declared outside of any function. They are accessible (visible) to all functions in the script. They stay in memory as long as the Web page is open in the browser.

questions.question: What is the result of using a variable inside a function without declaring it first with the 'var' keyword?
options: The computer will shut down immediately.
The variable will be treated as a Local variable by default.
JavaScript will automatically treat it as a Global variable.
The browser will ignore the entire function.
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, if you assign a value to a variable that hasn't been declared with 'var', it automatically becomes a Global variable, even if it is inside a function. This can lead to errors, so it is safer to always use 'var' for local variables.

questions.question: Which of the following is a benefit of using Local variables over Global variables?
options: Local variables make the code run 100 times faster.
They prevent different functions from accidentally changing the same data.
Local variables are the only ones that can store images.
Global variables are illegal in modern Web development.
questions.explanation: Using local variables is 'safe' because they are isolated. Since they only exist within their own function, you don't have to worry about another function modifying them, which reduces bugs in large programs.

questions.question: Which specific JavaScript object is used to capture and store the current date and time from the user's computer system?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, the 'Date' object is used to work with dates and times. By creating a new instance of this object (e.g., 'var now = new Date();'), the script captures the current local date and time from the client's system clock. Options 0, 1, and 3 are not valid built-in JavaScript objects for this purpose.

questions.question: When using the 'getDay()' method of a Date object, what value is returned if the current day is Sunday?
questions.explanation: The 'getDay()' method returns an integer representing the day of the week, starting from 0 for Sunday, 1 for Monday, up to 6 for Saturday. This zero-based indexing is a common standard in JavaScript date methods. Option 2 is incorrect as the range is 0-6.

questions.question: Which method is used to extract the four-digit year (e.g., 2026) from a JavaScript Date object?
questions.explanation: The 'getFullYear()' method returns the year of the specified date according to local time as a four-digit number. While 'getYear()' exists, it is deprecated because it only returns a two-digit year or years since 1900, which led to Y2K-style issues. 'getFullYear()' is the modern, precise standard.

questions.question: In JavaScript, how does the 'getMonth()' method represent the month of January?
questions.explanation: Similar to days of the week, JavaScript months are zero-indexed. This means January is represented by 0, February by 1, and December by 11. This often requires developers to add 1 to the result when displaying the month to users in a standard 1-12 format.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the 'Math' object in JavaScript?
options: To provide a collection of mathematical constants and functions.
To manage the timing of function execution.
To define the layout and styling of HTML elements.
questions.explanation: The 'Math' object is a built-in object that has properties and methods for mathematical constants and functions, such as square roots (Math.sqrt), rounding (Math.round), and generating random numbers (Math.random). It is not a constructor; all its properties and methods are static.

questions.question: Which method of the Math object is used to round a number to the nearest integer?
questions.explanation: 'Math.round()' returns the value of a number rounded to the nearest integer. If the fractional part of the number is 0.5 or greater, the argument is rounded to the next higher integer. 'Math.ceil()' (Option 0) always rounds up, and 'Math.floor()' (Option 1) always rounds down.

questions.question: What is the range of numbers generated by the 'Math.random()' method?
questions.explanation: 'Math.random()' returns a floating-point, pseudo-random number in the range 0 to less than 1 (inclusive of 0, but not 1). To get a larger range, you must multiply the result by a factor (e.g., Math.random() * 10).

questions.question: Which Math method would you use to find the square root of 625?
questions.explanation: The 'Math.sqrt()' method is specifically designed to calculate the square root of a number. 'Math.pow(625, 2)' (Option 2) would calculate 625 squared (625 to the power of 2), which is 390,625.

questions.question: What is the result of 'Math.floor(4.9)' in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The 'Math.floor()' function returns the largest integer less than or equal to a given number. Even though 4.9 is very close to 5, 'floor' always 'drops' the decimal to the integer below, resulting in 4.

questions.question: Which specific operator is used in JavaScript to join two or more strings together?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, the plus (+) operator serves a dual purpose: it performs addition on numbers and 'concatenation' on strings. When used with strings, it joins them end-to-end to create a single new string. The dot operator (Option 0) is used to access object properties, not for joining text.

questions.question: In the context of 'Array' objects in JavaScript, how is the first element of an array indexed?
questions.explanation: JavaScript arrays use zero-based indexing. This means the very first item in the list is accessed using the index 0, the second with 1, and so on. This is a fundamental concept in programming that often leads to 'off-by-one' errors for beginners who expect counting to start at 1.

questions.question: What is the primary technical function of the 'Array.sort()' method?
options: To remove all duplicate elements from an array.
To arrange the elements of an array in a specific order (e.g., alphabetical).
To count the total number of items currently stored in the array.
To reverse the order of elements without changing their values.
questions.explanation: The 'sort()' method is used to organize the elements of an array. By default, it sorts elements alphabetically as strings. While it is powerful, developers must be careful when sorting numbers, as it may treat '10' as coming before '2' unless a comparison function is provided.

questions.question: Which method would you use to add a new element to the very end of an existing array?
questions.explanation: The 'push()' method adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length of the array. 'Append' (Option 2) is common in other languages like Python, but in JavaScript, 'push' is the standard method.

questions.question: Which method is used to remove the last element from an array?
questions.explanation: The 'pop()' method removes the last element from an array and returns that element. This changes the length of the array. 'shift()' (Option 3) removes the *first* element, not the last.

questions.question: Which method can be used to join all elements of an array into a single string, separated by a specific character like a comma?
questions.explanation: The 'join()' method creates and returns a new string by concatenating all of the elements in an array. You can specify a separator (like a space, comma, or hyphen) to be placed between the elements in the resulting string.

questions.question: Which method would you use to find the index of a specific item in an array (e.g., find where 'Apple' is in a fruit list)?
questions.explanation: The 'indexOf()' method returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array, or -1 if it is not present.

questions.question: Which property of a JavaScript Array object returns the total number of elements contained within that array?
questions.explanation: The 'length' property is used to determine how many items are in an array. It is an integer that is always one higher than the highest index in the array. For example, an array with 5 items has a length of 5, but its highest index is 4.

questions.question: When generating a random integer between 1 and 10, why is 'Math.floor()' often used with 'Math.random() * 10'?
options: To ensure the result is always a decimal value.
To remove the fractional part and round the number down to the nearest whole integer.
To force the computer to choose the highest possible number in the range.
To prevent the script from running more than ten times.
questions.explanation: Math.random() generates a decimal between 0 and 0.999... Multiplying by 10 gives a range from 0 to 9.999... 'Math.floor()' is used to 'drop' the decimal, giving us integers from 0 to 9. Adding 1 then shifts the range to 1 through 10. Without 'floor', the result would not be a clean integer.

questions.question: In JavaScript, what happens if you attempt to access an array index that does not exist (e.g., index 10 in an array of size 5)?
options: The program will immediately terminate with a fatal error.
The array will automatically expand to that size.
The browser will display a popup warning to the user.
questions.explanation: JavaScript is 'forgiving' with array boundaries. If you try to read a value at an index that hasn't been assigned, it returns 'undefined' rather than crashing the script. This is different from languages like C++ or Java, which would throw an 'Out of Bounds' exception.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct way to declare an empty array named 'studentNames'?
questions.explanation: While 'new Array()' is valid, the square bracket notation '[]' is the preferred and most common way to declare an array in JavaScript. Option 3 creates an object, not an array, and Option 2 refers to a different data structure not native to basic JavaScript.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of using an 'Array' instead of separate variables (e.g., student1, student2, student3)?
options: Arrays allow you to store data on the server instead of the client's computer.
Arrays allow you to manage a collection of related data using a single name and loops.
Arrays are the only way to store images in JavaScript.
Arrays automatically encrypt the data for better security.
questions.explanation: Arrays are essential for handling lists. By using a single variable name for a collection, you can use loops to process hundreds of items with just a few lines of code, which would be impossible if every item had its own unique variable name.

questions.question: What is the result of the JavaScript expression 'typeof [1, 2, 3]'?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, arrays are technically a specialized type of 'object'. Therefore, the 'typeof' operator returns 'object' when used on an array. To specifically check if something is an array, developers usually use 'Array.isArray()'.

questions.question: In a loop used to traverse an array, what is the standard condition to ensure the loop stops at the end of the array?
questions.explanation: Because array indexing starts at 0, the last index is always 'length - 1'. Therefore, the loop should continue as long as the index 'i' is *strictly less than* the length. Using '<=' (Option 0) would cause the loop to run one extra time, attempting to access an undefined index.

questions.question: If 'var colors = ["Red", "Green", "Blue"];', what is the value of 'colors[1]'?
questions.explanation: Remembering that indexing starts at 0: colors[0] is "Red", colors[1] is "Green", and colors[2] is "Blue". Thus, index 1 refers to the second item in the list.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between 'Math.ceil()' and 'Math.round()'?
options: Math.ceil() always rounds up to the next integer, while Math.round() rounds to the nearest integer.
Math.ceil() only works with negative numbers.
Math.round() always rounds up, while Math.ceil() rounds to the nearest.
There is no difference; they are synonyms for the same function.
questions.explanation: Math.ceil (ceiling) always pushes the number up to the next integer (e.g., 4.1 becomes 5). Math.round follows standard rounding rules: .5 and above go up, below .5 go down (e.g., 4.1 becomes 4).

questions.question: Which JavaScript method would you use to find the largest number in a set of arguments (e.g., 10, 50, 20)?
questions.explanation: The 'Math.max()' function returns the largest of zero or more numbers. Its counterpart is 'Math.min()', which returns the smallest value.

questions.question: What value does 'Math.PI' provide in JavaScript?
options: A function to calculate the area of a circle.
A variable that counts the number of pages in a document.
The value of the user's IP address.
questions.explanation: Math.PI is a property of the Math object representing the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, approximately 3.14159. It is a constant, not a function.

questions.question: What is the value of 'Math.abs(-5)'?
questions.explanation: The 'Math.abs()' function returns the absolute value of a number, which is its distance from zero. It essentially removes the negative sign if one exists.

questions.question: What does 'Math.pow(2, 3)' calculate?
questions.explanation: Math.pow(base, exponent) calculates the base raised to the power of the exponent. 2 to the 3rd power is 8.

questions.question: What is the output of 'Math.round(4.5)'?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, .5 rounds up to the next largest integer. Therefore, 4.5 becomes 5.

questions.question: In JavaScript, what is the purpose of the 'new' keyword when working with Dates?
options: To delete an old date and start over.
To create a new 'instance' or object from the Date constructor.
To update the computer's system clock to the current time.
To declare a variable that cannot be changed.
questions.explanation: The 'new' keyword is used to create an instance of an object type that has a constructor function. When you say 'new Date()', you are creating a unique object that contains the current date/time data and all the date methods.

questions.question: Which method of the Date object returns the current hour (0-23)?
questions.explanation: The 'getHours()' method returns the hour for the specified date according to local time. The value returned is an integer between 0 and 23. Note the 's' at the end of the method name.

questions.question: Which method returns the numeric day of the month (1-31) from a Date object?
questions.explanation: This is a common point of confusion: 'getDay()' returns the day of the week (0-6), while 'getDate()' returns the actual day of the month (1-31).

questions.question: How can you get the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since January 1, 1970?
questions.explanation: The 'Date.now()' method returns the number of milliseconds elapsed since the 'Unix Epoch' (Jan 1, 1970). This is a common way to measure time intervals or create unique timestamps in programming.

questions.question: If you want to display 'Good Evening' only if the current hour is 18 (6 PM) or later, which condition is correct?
questions.explanation: The 'greater than or equal to' operator (>=) ensures the message displays exactly at 18:00 and all hours following until midnight. Option 1 would only work for the 6 PM hour specifically.

questions.question: What is the correct way to write a JavaScript array literal?
questions.explanation: Square brackets [] are used for arrays. Parentheses () are for functions/grouping, and curly braces {} are for objects.

questions.question: In the 'Introduction to Computing' course, why are JavaScript arrays discussed alongside Loops?
options: Because loops are the only way to create an array.
Because loops provide a powerful way to perform an action on every item in an array efficiently.
Because both were invented by the same person at Bell Labs.
Because arrays cannot exist without a 'for' loop.
questions.explanation: Arrays and loops are 'best friends' in programming. While an array stores the list, a loop allows you to go through that list (traversal) and perform tasks like printing names or calculating sums without writing repetitive code.

questions.question: In a roll-over script, why do we often use a variable to track if an image is already 'active'?
options: To stop the computer from running out of memory.
To prevent the roll-over animation from restarting unnecessarily if the mouse is already over the target.
To change the color of the browser's scroll bar.
To count how many times the user has visited the website.
questions.explanation: Using a state variable (like 'isOver') allows the script to check the current status of the image. This logic ensures that the 'onMouseOver' code only executes once when the mouse enters, rather than firing repeatedly, which saves processing power and prevents visual glitches.

questions.question: In a JavaScript animation script, what is the best way to handle 50 different images?
options: Create 50 different variables named img1, img2, etc.
Use an Array to store 50 Image objects and a Loop to preload them.
Download them one by one only when needed.
Tell the user to download the images manually.
questions.explanation: Using an array and a loop is the most efficient way to manage a collection of objects. It allows you to preload and access all 50 frames using a single variable name and an index, making the code much shorter and more robust.

questions.question: If you use 'Math.random()' to pick a winner from an array of 5 students, what should you multiply the random number by?
questions.explanation: Multiplying by the length of the array (5) results in a number between 0 and 4.999... When passed through 'Math.floor()', this gives the integers 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4, which correspond to the indices of a 5-item array.

questions.question: In JavaScript, a string is treated as:
questions.explanation: Strings behave similarly to arrays in JavaScript. You can access individual characters using indices (e.g., 'hello'[0] is 'h') and check their length using the '.length' property.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about JavaScript Date objects?
options: They automatically update every second in the background.
They are static snapshots of the time at the moment they were created.
They show the exact same time for every user in the world regardless of location.
They can only be used on Monday through Friday.
questions.explanation: A Date object captures the time *at the moment the code runs*. If you want to show a ticking clock, you must create a new Date object (or update an existing one) repeatedly using a timer function.

questions.question: Which specific JavaScript object is used to capture and display images on a Web page, allowing for techniques like image preloading?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, the 'Image' object is used to represent and manipulate images. As detailed in the CS101 handouts, this object can be used to download an image into the browser's cache before it is actually needed for display, ensuring smooth animations and faster page responses. Options 0, 1, and 3 are not valid built-in JavaScript object names.

questions.question: In the context of the CS101 course, what is the 'Image()' constructor used for?
options: To create a new, empty image placeholder in the computer's memory.
To physically print a hard copy of a digital photograph.
To delete an image from a Web page permanently.
To increase the resolution of a low-quality bitmapped graphic.
questions.explanation: The syntax 'var myImage = new Image();' creates a new instance of the Image object in the browser's RAM. This instance doesn't appear on the screen immediately but serves as a container that can be used for preloading or programmatic manipulation of graphics.

questions.question: Which syntax correctly assigns a source to a preloaded Image object named 'myPic'?
questions.explanation: The '.src' property is the standard way to assign the file path to an Image object. Once this line executes, the browser begins the background download into the cache.

questions.question: Which property can be used to check the width of an Image object in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The '.width' property of an Image object returns the horizontal dimension of the image in pixels. This can be used to dynamically adjust layouts in a script.

questions.question: What is the primary technical advantage of 'Image Preloading' in Web development?
options: It reduces the physical file size of the image on the server.
It stores images in the user's cache before they are needed, preventing delays during display.
It automatically converts color images into black and white to save power.
It allows images to be displayed even if the user has no internet connection.
questions.explanation: Image preloading involves creating an Image object in JavaScript and assigning it a source (URL). The browser then downloads the image into the local cache. When the image is later called for display (e.g., during a mouse-over event), it appears instantly because it is already stored locally, avoiding the 'flicker' caused by downloading on demand.

questions.question: Which specific JavaScript object is used to perform preloading of graphics, as discussed in the final CS101 lecture?
questions.explanation: The 'Image' object in JavaScript is used to download images into the browser's cache before they are needed for display. This technique is essential for creating smooth animations and responsive user interfaces, ensuring that the user does not experience delays or flickers when an image is swapped.

questions.question: Which technique allows a developer to ensure an animation is smooth by storing image frames locally in the user's browser?
questions.explanation: Image Preloading downloads images into the client's cache. By the time the animation script calls for a frame, the image is already available locally, allowing the animation to cycle through images without waiting for network downloads.

questions.question: In the context of the course conclusion, what is the 'Image()' constructor used for in a script?
options: To create a new instance of an image object for preloading.
To delete a file from the hard drive.
To change the browser's background color.
questions.explanation: The 'Image()' constructor is the syntax used to create a new Image object in JavaScript. Once created, its 'src' property can be set to a URL, which triggers the preloading process into the browser's cache.

questions.question: How does the Image object improve the display of images based on specific requirements?
options: By increasing the internet connection speed.
By allowing the display of one of several images instantly from the cache.
By automatically correcting the colors in the image.
By translating text found inside the image.
questions.explanation: When images are preloaded, the browser can switch between them instantly. This is particularly useful for interactive elements or conditions where a specific image must be shown based on user input without any loading delay.

questions.question: In JavaScript, setting the '.src' property of a new Image object triggers which action?
options: The downloading of the image into the local cache.
The immediate printing of the web page.
The opening of a new browser window.
questions.explanation: As soon as the 'src' property of an Image object is assigned a URL, the browser begins fetching that file. Since it's stored in the cache, any future requests for that same URL will be handled locally, which is the basis of preloading.

questions.question: Which JavaScript property is used to specify the location (URL) of an image file for an Image object?
questions.explanation: The 'src' (source) property is used to define the path to the image file. Once the 'src' property of a JavaScript Image object is set, the browser immediately begins downloading that image into its cache. This is the same attribute name used in the HTML tag.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a property of the JavaScript Image object?
questions.explanation: Width, height, and src are all properties (characteristics) of an Image object. 'calculate()' is a method name and is not a standard part of the Image object's property list in JavaScript.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the most common use of the 'onMouseOver' and 'onMouseOut' events with the Image object?
options: To encrypt the image data for secure transmission.
To create 'Roll-over' effects where an image changes when the mouse moves over it.
To automatically resize the browser window to match the image size.
To play a sound file associated with the image.
questions.explanation: A 'Roll-over' is a common UI technique where one image is swapped for another when a user hovers their mouse over it. By using 'onMouseOver' to switch the 'src' to a preloaded second image and 'onMouseOut' to switch it back, developers create an interactive, responsive experience.

questions.question: According to the CS101 handouts, what is the main purpose of achieving 'beginner proficiency' in Web page development?
options: To become a professional software engineer immediately after the course.
To build an appreciation for the fundamental concepts and create functional websites.
To learn how to repair physical computer hardware and circuitry.
To master high-level data science and machine learning algorithms.
questions.explanation: The course objectives state that the goal is to build an appreciation for fundamental computing concepts and achieve a beginner-level proficiency. This includes understanding how HTML and JavaScript work together to provide interactivity and structure on the Web.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key objective of the CS101 course at Virtual University?
options: To provide a detailed history of the Pakistan military.
To build an appreciation for the fundamental concepts in computing.
To teach students how to build their own physical hard drives.
To replace the need for any further computer science education.
questions.explanation: As stated in the handouts, the first objective of the course is 'To build an appreciation for the fundamental concepts in computing.' This provides the theoretical foundation upon which practical skills like programming and software use are built.

questions.question: According to the CS101 course objectives, what level of skill was intended for Web page development?
questions.explanation: The handouts explicitly state that the second course objective was to 'achieve a beginners proficiency in Web page development.' This level provides students with a foundational understanding of how HTML and JavaScript interact to build functional websites.

questions.question: When building an appreciation for computing, which of the following is considered a 'fundamental concept' in the CS101 handouts?
options: The price of modern graphics cards.
The logic and structure of algorithms.
How to physically clean a computer monitor.
The history of mobile phone networks.
questions.explanation: One of the primary objectives of the course is to build an appreciation for fundamental concepts like algorithms, data structures, and computer architecture. These are the theoretical building blocks that underpin all of computing.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three primary course objectives mentioned in the final lecture?
options: To build an appreciation for fundamental concepts.
To achieve beginner proficiency in Web development.
To become an expert in computer hardware repair.
To become familiar with popular productivity software.
questions.explanation: The three objectives are: fundamental concepts, beginner web development, and familiarity with productivity software. Hardware repair was never a stated objective of the CS101 Introduction to Computing course.

questions.question: What is the result of achieving the first objective of the CS101 course?
options: The ability to build a microprocessor from scratch.
An appreciation for the fundamental concepts in computing.
The ability to fix any broken software.
questions.explanation: The first objective is explicitly 'To build an appreciation for the fundamental concepts in computing.' This involves understanding the 'why' and 'how' behind computer operations, rather than just rote software usage.

questions.question: Which objective reflects the practical side of the Web-related lectures in CS101?
options: Objective 2: Beginners proficiency in Web page development
questions.explanation: Objective 2 is the practical application of web technologies. By learning HTML and basic JavaScript (including the Image object), students move beyond theory into creating actual, interactive web content.

questions.question: How did the CS101 assignments help achieve the course objectives?
options: By testing students on their ability to repair hardware.
By providing practical experience in web development and productivity tasks.
By requiring students to memorize the birth dates of computer scientists.
By forcing students to buy expensive textbooks.
questions.explanation: Assignments in CS101 are designed to apply the theory learned in lectures. Whether coding a simple web page or creating a document, they reinforce the goal of achieving beginner-level proficiency.

questions.question: What does the 'Appreciation' objective aim to change in a student?
options: Their understanding of the fundamental nature and power of computing.
The brand of computer they use.
questions.explanation: Building an appreciation means moving from a 'user' to a 'knower.' It helps students understand the significance of technology and how it shapes the modern world, which is a key academic goal of CS101.

questions.question: Why is it important for the 'src' property of a preloaded image to be set in the <HEAD> section or early in the script?
options: To prevent the computer from overheating.
To ensure the image is downloaded and ready before the user interacts with the page.
Because images cannot be downloaded in the <BODY> section.
To hide the image source code from the user.
questions.explanation: If the script waits until the user clicks a button to start downloading an image, there will be a noticeable delay. By defining and loading the Image object early (usually in the header functions), the asset is already in the cache when the user's action triggers its display.

questions.question: When an image is preloaded into the 'Cache', where is that data physically stored?
options: In the user's local RAM or temporary disk storage.
questions.explanation: The 'Cache' is a temporary storage area on the client's (user's) computer. By storing frequently used data or preloaded images locally in RAM or on the hard drive, the browser avoids repeated network requests, significantly improving speed and performance.

questions.question: In JavaScript, if you have an image tag , how do you change its image to 'b.gif' using its name?
questions.explanation: In the Document Object Model (DOM), images are properties of the 'document' object. You can access an image by the name assigned in the HTML tag and then manipulate its 'src' property to change the displayed image dynamically.

questions.question: What happens if a preloaded image is larger than the display area of the tag it eventually replaces?
options: The image will be automatically cropped from the center.
The image will be squashed or stretched to fit the tag's dimensions.
The browser will refuse to display the image.
questions.explanation: When you swap the 'src' of an existing HTML tag, the new image will be forced to conform to the 'width' and 'height' attributes defined in the original tag. This can cause distortion if the aspect ratios of the two images do not match.

questions.question: To create an array of 5 preloaded images, which syntax is most efficient?
options: var pix = new Array(5); for(i=0; i<5; i++) { pix[i] = new Image(); }
questions.explanation: By combining arrays, loops, and the Image constructor, you can efficiently manage multiple images. The loop creates a new Image object instance for every index in the array, allowing you to then assign 'src' values to 'pix[0].src', 'pix[1].src', etc.

questions.question: What is the result of assigning a new URL to an existing image's .src property while the page is still loading?
options: The browser cancels the current page load.
The browser adds the new request to the download queue.
The browser ignores the new request until the page is refreshed.
The browser replaces the HTML file with the image file.
questions.explanation: Browsers are designed to handle multiple simultaneous requests. Assigning a new .src property triggers a new asynchronous GET request for that asset, which is managed by the browser's networking layer without stopping the rendering of the rest of the page.

questions.question: What is the term for a single frame in a JavaScript-based animation?
questions.explanation: In simple JavaScript animations (like a flickering bulb or a moving character), each 'frame' is represented by a different image file. The animation is created by rapidly cycling through these different image states using a timer or event handler.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the 'completeness' of a software help manual?
options: It should only contain the name of the software creator.
It should provide clear instructions for every feature and task the software can perform.
It should be written in binary code to save space.
It is unnecessary if the software is 'Good' software.
questions.explanation: According to the 'Attributes of Good Software,' a complete help manual is essential. Even if software is intuitive, users need a comprehensive reference to troubleshoot issues or learn advanced features they may not discover on their own.

questions.question: What is 'Configurable' software?
options: Software that can only be installed on one specific computer.
Software that allows the user to change settings (like colors or shortcuts) to suit their preferences.
Software that automatically changes its own code every day.
Software that does not require a license to use.
questions.explanation: Configurability allows software to adapt to different user needs. For example, a word processor that lets you customize the toolbar or a game that lets you change the screen resolution is considered configurable.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a 'Critical Bug'?
options: A small misspelling in the help manual.
A flaw that causes the software to crash, lose data, or fail its primary function.
The software's icon is the wrong color.
The software takes 2 seconds longer to load than expected.
questions.explanation: Critical bugs are severe issues that prevent the software from being usable or safe. Good software should be free of these major flaws to ensure reliability and user trust.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key attribute of 'Good' software according to the course?
options: It must be the most expensive option available.
It should be intuitive and free of critical bugs.
It should only work on Virtual University computers.
It should require 10 years of training to use.
questions.explanation: As discussed throughout the software lectures, usability (being intuitive) and reliability (no critical bugs) are the hallmarks of high-quality application software.

questions.question: Which attribute of an image tag specifies the text that appears if the image fails to load?
questions.explanation: The 'alt' (alternative text) attribute provides a text description of the image. This is crucial for accessibility (screen readers) and for situations where the image cannot be displayed due to a broken link or slow connection.

questions.question: How does the browser identify which tag to update when a JavaScript statement like 'document.pic1.src = ...' is executed?
options: By the 'name' or 'id' attribute assigned to the tag in HTML.
By the order in which the images were uploaded to the server.
By the color of the image's border.
questions.explanation: The 'name' attribute (in older HTML) or 'id' attribute (in modern HTML) acts as a unique identifier for elements within the document. JavaScript uses these identifiers to target and modify specific elements without affecting others on the page.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a 'Trivial Task' in productivity software, as mentioned in the CS101 closing lecture?
options: Writing a complex operating system from scratch.
Opening a package and performing basic operations like typing or saving.
Setting up a global telecommunications network.
questions.explanation: The course objective for productivity software was not to make students experts, but to give them the ability to perform 'trivial tasks'—basic, everyday operations like opening a file, editing text, or creating a simple spreadsheet—to build a foundation for future career growth.

questions.question: What was the primary goal for students regarding PC productivity software in the CS101 course?
options: To become certified experts in MS Office.
To become familiar with popular PC productivity software and perform trivial tasks.
To learn how to program the internal logic of spreadsheets.
To replace the need for professional accounting software.
questions.explanation: The lectures were designed to give a brief introduction so that students become able to 'open the package and perform some trivial tasks.' Expertise is expected to develop gradually over time as students use these packages in their careers.

questions.question: What does the instructor suggest will happen with your skills in productivity software after the course concludes?
options: They will immediately fade if not used daily.
You will gradually develop an expertise that will become very useful in your career.
You will need to take another 10 courses to be useful.
The software will become obsolete within six months.
questions.explanation: The instructor notes that with time, students will find more use for these packages and develop an expertise through practice. This perspective emphasizes that the course provided the starting point (beginner proficiency) for long-term skill development.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the level of proficiency intended for MS Word or Excel in this course?
options: None; they were only mentioned briefly.
Ability to perform trivial tasks and navigate the package.
questions.explanation: The course intended for students to become 'familiar' and able to 'perform some trivial tasks.' This foundational knowledge allows students to grow their skills as they encounter more complex needs in their professional lives.

questions.question: What is meant by 'Trivial Tasks' in the context of productivity software lectures?
options: Basic operations like opening a file, entering data, or saving.
questions.explanation: Trivial tasks refer to basic, entry-level operations. The course aim was to ensure students could start using the software for simple needs, serving as a gateway to more advanced usage later on.

questions.question: Why did the CS101 course include a 'brief introduction' to productivity software rather than an exhaustive training?
options: Because the software is not important for careers.
Because expertise develops over time through real-world use.
Because there was not enough space on the VU servers.
Because the instructor did not know how to use it.
questions.explanation: The philosophy shared in the final lecture is that expertise is a gradual process. The course provides the initial familiarity, and true expertise is built through continued use and finding more applications for the software in one's career.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about 'Expertise' in software packages like MS Word?
options: It can be fully mastered in a single one-hour lecture.
It is a useful skill that develops as you use the package for more and more tasks.
It is only necessary for computer scientists, not other professionals.
It makes the computer run faster.
questions.explanation: As stated in the handouts, expertise is something that 'gradually develops' and eventually becomes 'very useful in your career.' It is a cumulative skill set built on a foundation of basic familiarity.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a 'Trivial Task' in MS Excel?
options: Writing an AI to predict the stock market.
Opening a spreadsheet and entering a column of numbers.
Building a physical computer from silicon.
questions.explanation: Simple data entry and navigation are the types of 'trivial tasks' the course aimed to teach. These basic skills are the necessary first steps before moving on to complex data analysis.

questions.question: What is the standard file extension for a static image commonly used on the Web for logos and simple graphics?
questions.explanation: GIF (Graphics Interchange Format) is a widely used format for web images, especially those with solid colors like logos. Other common web formats include JPEG (for photos) and PNG. .exe is an executable program, .txt is plain text, and .mp3 is audio.

questions.question: In the JavaScript statement 'var temp = new Image();', 'temp' is a/an:
questions.explanation: 'temp' is a variable name that holds a reference to the newly created Image object. It allows you to access and change that object's properties (like temp.src) later in the script.

questions.question: Why is 'Intuitive' design a requirement for good application software?
options: So that the software doesn't require any memory to run.
So that a user can figure out how to use the basic features with little to no training.
So that the software can translate itself into different languages automatically.
So that the software can run without an operating system.
questions.explanation: Intuitive software follows common conventions (like a disk icon for saving), making it easy for users to apply their existing knowledge to new programs. This reduces the 'learning curve' and improves user satisfaction.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of images that can be preloaded in a single Web page?
options: There is no fixed limit, but it is limited by the computer's available memory.
questions.explanation: While there is no hard-coded limit in JavaScript, every preloaded image consumes RAM. Preloading hundreds of large images can slow down the user's computer or cause the browser to become unresponsive, so it should be used judiciously.

questions.question: Which method is used to clear the status bar text when the mouse moves away from a link?
questions.explanation: To 'clear' the status bar, you simply set the 'status' property of the window object to an empty string (""). This is usually done inside an 'onMouseOut' event handler.

questions.question: Which method would you use to change the current window's location to a new URL?
questions.explanation: The 'location' property of the window object can be assigned a new URL (e.g., window.location = 'newsite.com') to redirect the browser to a different page.

questions.question: In the statement 'document.images[0].src', what does the '[0]' represent?
options: The first image in the HTML document.
The last image in the HTML document.
An image that has been deleted.
The size of the image in kilobytes.
questions.explanation: The 'images' object is an array-like collection of all tags in a document. Like all JavaScript arrays, it is zero-indexed, so document.images[0] refers to the very first image that appears in the HTML code.

questions.question: What does the 'new' keyword signify in the expression 'var x = new Image();'?
options: That the variable 'x' is a brand new name.
That we are creating a new object based on the 'Image' blueprint (constructor).
That we are deleting the old version of the browser.
That the image being loaded is a new version of an old file.
questions.explanation: The 'new' keyword is used to 'instantiate' an object. It tells JavaScript to allocate memory for a new object and run the constructor function (in this case, Image()) to initialize that object.

questions.question: In a sequence of images used for animation, why is it important to use images of the same dimensions?
options: Otherwise, the browser will refuse to play the animation.
To avoid visual 'jumping' or distortion as the browser resizes to fit different frames.
Because images of different sizes cannot be stored in the same array.
To save space on the user's hard drive.
questions.explanation: If the frames of an animation have different widths or heights, the tag will either resize (causing a 'jumpy' effect) or the images will be distorted to fit the fixed tag size. Consistency ensures a smooth, professional-looking animation.

questions.question: What is 'Shareware'?
options: Software that is owned by everyone and has no copyright.
Software that can be tried for free but requires payment for continued use or extra features.
Software that only works if you share it with 10 other people.
A hardware device used to share a single printer between two computers.
questions.explanation: Shareware is a distribution model where users are encouraged to share and try the software. However, it is not 'free' software; it usually has a trial period or limited features, and the user is legally/ethically expected to pay for a full license if they continue to use it.

questions.question: In JavaScript, 'document' is a/an:
questions.explanation: In the browser hierarchy, 'window' is the top-level object. The 'document' object is a property of the window object that represents the actual HTML page loaded in that window.

questions.question: According to the CS101 final lecture, what is the best way to develop expertise in productivity software?
options: By reading the entire manual without ever opening the software.
By gradually using the packages for real tasks and developing skills over time.
By memorizing the names of every menu item in MS Word.
By waiting until you are hired for a job to start learning.
questions.explanation: The handouts emphasize that expertise comes with time and practice. By starting with trivial tasks and gradually using productivity software for more complex needs, students develop the practical skills necessary for their future careers.

questions.question: In the final lecture summary, what does the instructor ask students to do regarding the course objectives?
options: Let the university know how successful they were in achieving them.
Ignore the objectives and focus on the final grade.
Pay extra fees for the next semester.
questions.explanation: The instructor explicitly asks for feedback: 'Please do let us know so that we can modify the future offerings of this course accordingly.' This shows an emphasis on continuous improvement of the curriculum.

questions.question: In the concluding remarks, what does 'until the next time when we meet' imply?
options: That the student has failed the course.
The end of the current course sessions and a wish for future interaction.
That the student must physically visit the instructor's house.
That the computer will stay turned on until the next lecture.
questions.explanation: This is a standard formal closing for a series of lectures, marking the completion of the syllabus while maintaining a professional and encouraging tone for the students' future academic journeys.

questions.question: What is the final message of the instructor in the CS101 handouts?
options: An expression of enjoyment and a hope that the course was useful.
An announcement of a new career in acting.
questions.explanation: The instructor ends on a positive and professional note, thanking the students for their attention and contributions (emails and discussion board messages) and wishing them well in their future endeavors.

questions.question: What is a 'Roll-over' effect in web design?
options: When a web page automatically reloads every minute.
When an image changes into another one when the mouse moves over it.
When the text on a page scrolls horizontally.
questions.explanation: Roll-overs are a prime example of the interactivity taught in the course. They rely on event handlers (onMouseOver/onMouseOut) and often utilize preloaded images to ensure the change happens instantly without a 'flicker.'

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of the 'Cache' in the context of image preloading?
options: It increases the storage capacity of the hard drive.
It stores data closer to the user to speed up access times.
It makes the internet connection wireless.
It prevents the user from seeing the source code.
questions.explanation: The cache is a high-speed data storage layer. By preloading images into the browser's cache, the browser can retrieve them instantly from the local computer rather than downloading them again from the web server.

questions.question: How does preloading prevent 'flicker' in web animations?
options: By slowing down the browser so it has time to think.
By ensuring the next image is already in memory before it needs to be shown.
By turning off the monitor's refresh rate.
By using only black and white images.
questions.explanation: A 'flicker' occurs when a browser tries to display an image it hasn't downloaded yet, showing an empty space briefly. Preloading ensures the image is ready in the cache, allowing for an instantaneous swap that looks smooth to the human eye.

questions.question: According to the course summary, why was only a 'brief introduction' given to some topics?
options: To avoid overwhelming the student and provide a starting point for self-growth.
Because the instructor forgot the rest of the material.
Because the university has a policy against long lectures.
Because those topics are not relevant to modern computing.
questions.explanation: The philosophy of CS101 is to build a foundation. By providing a brief but solid introduction, students are equipped to explore further and develop their own expertise as their needs evolve.
